DOC.HEAD: Soviets Condemn U.S. Attack on Noriega
Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Radio Moscow condemning the attack, later Tass report identifying the Foreign Ministry official. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union on Wednesday swiftly condemned the U.S. armed intervention in Panama and demanded it end immediately. ``The United States has launched an act of aggression against Panama,'' state-run Radio Moscow reported. It said the Central American country was the victim of an American military ``invasion.'' ``These actions, a violation of the U.N. Charter and generally recognized rules of state relations, should be condemned by the international community,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim P. Perfiliev said. ``The United States must immediately stop its armed intervention in Panama.'' Perfiliev was quoted by the official Tass news agency as saying that the U.S. action, ``whatever its motivation, has provoked a feeling of serious concern in the Soviet Union.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush ordered U.S. troops to seize the Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and bring him to the United States for trial on federal drug charges. Tass said Perfiliev commented in response to questions from reporters.
